column1: Fairbanks (Lower Tanana: Tanan) is a home rule city and the borough seat of the Fairbanks North Star Borough in the U.S. state of Alaska.Fairbanks is the largest city in the Interior region of Alaska. 2019 estimates put the population of the city proper at 30
column3: and the population of the Fairbanks North Star Borough at 96
column5: making it the second most populous metropolitan area in Alaska (after Anchorage). The Metropolitan Statistical Area encompasses all of the Fairbanks North Star Borough and is the northernmost Metropolitan Statistical Area in the United States
column6: located 196 miles (315 kilometers) by road (140 mi or 230 km by air) south of the Arctic Circle. Fairbanks is home to the University of Alaska Fairbanks
column7: the founding campus of the University of Alaska system.

column1: Athabascan peoples have used the area for thousands of years
column2: although there is no known permanent Alaska Native settlement at the site of Fairbanks. An archaeological site excavated on the grounds of the University of Alaska Fairbanks uncovered a Native camp about 3
column4: with older remains found at deeper levels. From evidence gathered at the site
column5: archaeologists surmise that Native activities in the area were limited to seasonal hunting and fishing as frigid temperatures precluded berry gathering. In addition
column6: archaeological sites on the grounds of nearby Fort Wainwright date back well over 10
column7: 000 years. Arrowheads excavated from the University of Alaska Fairbanks site matched similar items found in Asia
column8: providing some of the first evidence that humans arrived in North America via the Bering Strait land bridge in deep antiquity.

column1: Captain E. T. Barnette founded Fairbanks in August 1901 while headed to Tanacross (or Tanana Crossing
column2: where the Valdez–Eagle trail crossed the Tanana River)
column3: where he intended to set up a trading post. The steamboat on which Barnette was a passenger
column4: the Lavelle Young
column5: ran aground while attempting to negotiate shallow water. Barnette
column6: along with his party and supplies
column7: were deposited along the banks of the Chena River 7 miles (11 km) upstream from its confluence with the Tanana River. The sight of smoke from the steamer's engines caught the attention of gold prospectors working in the hills to the north
column8: most notably an Italian immigrant named Felice Pedroni (better known as Felix Pedro) and his partner Tom Gilmore. The two met Barnette where he disembarked and convinced him of the potential of the area. Barnette set up his trading post at the site
column9: still intending to eventually make it to Tanacross. Teams of gold prospectors soon congregated in and around the newly founded Fairbanks; they built drift mines
column11: and lode mines in addition to panning and sluicing.After some urging by James Wickersham
column12: who later moved the seat of the Third Division court from Eagle to Fairbanks
column13: the settlement was named after Charles W. Fairbanks
column14: a Republican senator from Indiana and later the twenty-sixth Vice President of the United States
column15: serving under Theodore Roosevelt during his second term.In these early years of settlement
column16: the Tanana Valley was an important agricultural center for Alaska until the establishment of the Matanuska Valley Colonization Project and the town of Palmer in 1935. Agricultural activity still occurs today in the Tanana Valley
column17: but mostly to the southeast of Fairbanks in the communities of Salcha and Delta Junction. During the early days of Fairbanks
column18: its vicinity was a major producer of agricultural goods. What is now the northern reaches of South Fairbanks was originally the farm of Paul J. Rickert
column19: who came from nearby Chena in 1904 and operated a large farm until his death in 1938. Farmers Loop Road and Badger Road
column20: loop roads north and east (respectively) of Fairbanks
column21: were also home to major farming activity. Badger Road is named for Harry Markley Badger
column22: an early resident of Fairbanks who later established a farm along the road and became known as "the Strawberry King". Ballaine and McGrath Roads
column23: side roads of Farmers Loop Road
column24: were also named for prominent local farmers
column25: whose farms were in the immediate vicinity of their respective namesake roads. Despite early efforts by the Alaska Loyal League
column26: the Tanana Valley Agriculture Association and William Fentress Thompson
column27: the editor-publisher of the Fairbanks Daily News-Miner
column29: agriculture in the area was never able to fully support the population
column30: although it came close in the 1920s.The construction of Ladd Army Airfield starting in 1939
column31: part of a larger effort by the federal government during the New Deal and World War II to install major infrastructure in the territory for the first time
column32: fostered an economic and population boom in Fairbanks which extended beyond the end of the war. In the 1940s the Canol pipeline extended north from Whitehorse for a few years. The Haines - Fairbanks 626 mile long 8" petroleum products pipeline was constructed during the period 1953-55. The presence of the U.S. military has remained strong in Fairbanks. Ladd became Fort Wainwright in 1960; the post was annexed into Fairbanks city limits during the 1980s.

column1: Fairbanks suffered from several floods in its first seven decades
column2: whether from ice jams during spring breakup or heavy rainfall. The first bridge crossing the Chena River
column3: a wooden structure built in 1904 to extend Turner Street northward to connect with the wagon roads leading to the gold mining camps
column4: often washed out before a permanent bridge was constructed at Cushman Street in 1917 by the Alaska Road Commission. On August 14
column6: after record rainfall upstream
column7: the Chena began to surge over its banks
column8: flooding almost the entire town of Fairbanks overnight. This disaster led to the creation of the Chena River Lakes Flood Control Project
column9: which built and operates the 50-foot-high (15 m) Moose Creek Dam in the Chena River and accompanying 8-mile-long (13 km) spillway. The project was designed to prevent a repetition of the 1967 flood by being able to divert water in the Chena upstream from Fairbanks into the Tanana River

column1: Fairbanks is in the central Tanana Valley
column2: straddling the Chena River near its confluence with the Tanana River. Immediately north of the city is a chain of hills that rises gradually until it reaches the White Mountains and the Yukon River. The city's southern border is the Tanana River. South of the river is the Tanana Flats
column3: an area of marsh and bog that stretches for more than 100 miles (160 km) until it rises into the Alaska Range
column4: which is visible from Fairbanks on clear days. To the east and west are low valleys separated by ridges of hills up to 3
column5: 000 feet (910 m) above sea level.The Tanana Valley is crossed by many low streams and rivers that flow into the Tanana River. In Fairbanks
column6: the Chena River flows southwest until it empties into the Tanana. Noyes Slough
column7: which heads and foots off the Chena River
column9: a district connected to the rest of Fairbanks by bridges and culverted roads.According to the United States Census Bureau
column10: the city has an area of 32.7 square miles (85 km2); 31.9 square miles (83 km2) of it is land and 0.8 square miles (2.1 km2) of it (2.48%) is water.

column1: The city is extremely far north
column2: being close to 16 degrees north of the Pacific border between the U.S. and Canada. It is on roughly the same parallel as the northern Swedish city of Skellefteå and Finnish city of Oulu. On account of its warm summers
column4: Fairbanks is south of the arctic tree line.

column1: Fairbanks’ climate is classified as subarctic (Köppen Dfc close to Dwc)
column2: with long cold winters and short warm summers. October through January are the snowiest months
column3: and snow is limited from February to May. On average
column4: the season's first snow falls on September 21
column5: the first inch of snow accumulates by October 8 and the last inch of snow falls on April 27. The last flurries happen in April on average
column6: but it occasionally does flurry in May. The snowpack is established by October 18
column8: and remains until April 23. Snow occasionally arrives early and in large amounts. On September 13
column10: 8 inches (20 cm) of snow fell in the city
column11: bending trees still laden with fall leaves. That September was also one of the snowiest on record
column13: compared to a median of only 0.3 inches or 0.0076 metres during the month. October and November are the snowiest months
column15: March and April are not very snowy
column16: as these are typically very dry months in central Alaska. The snowiest season has been from July 1990 to June 1991 with 147.3 inches (3.74 m)
column17: whilst the least snowy was from July 1918 to June 1919 with only 12.0 inches (0.30 m).The average first and last dates with a freezing temperature are September 9 and May 15
column19: allowing a growing season of 116 days
column20: although freezes have occurred in June
column22: and August and the last light frost is often in early June and the first light fall frost is often in late August or early September.Fairbanks is the coldest large city in the U.S.; normal monthly  mean temperatures range from −7.9 °F (−22.2 °C) in January to 62.5 °F (16.9 °C) in July. On average
column23: temperatures reach −40 °F (−40 °C) and 80 °F (27 °C) on 7.3 and 13 days annually
column25: and the last year that failed to reach the former mark was 2016. Between 1995 and 2008
column27: Fairbanks failed to record a temperature of 90 °F or 32 °C. The highest recorded temperature in Fairbanks was 99 °F (37 °C) on July 28
column29: compared to the Alaska-wide record high temperature of 100 °F (38 °C)
column30: recorded in Fort Yukon. The lowest was −66 °F (−54 °C) on January 14
column31: 1934. The warmest calendar year in Fairbanks was 1926
column32: when the average annual temperature was 32.4 °F (0.2 °C)
column33: while the coldest was 1956 with an annual mean temperature of 21.3 °F (−5.9 °C). The warmest month has been July 1975 with a monthly mean of 68.4 °F (20.2 °C) and the coldest January 1906 which averaged −36.4 °F (−38.0 °C). Low temperatures below 0 °F or −18 °C have been recorded in every month outside June through September. The record cold daily maximum is −58 °F (−50 °C) on January 18
column35: and the record warm daily minimum is 76 °F (24 °C) on June 26
column36: 1915; the only other occurrence of a 70 °F (21 °C) daily minimum was June 25
column37: 2013 in the midst of a particularly warm summer.These widely varying temperature extremes are due to three main factors: temperature inversions
column40: Fairbanks' low-lying location at the bottom of the Tanana Valley causes cold air to accumulate in and around the city. Warmer air rises to the tops of the hills north of Fairbanks
column41: while the city itself experiences one of the biggest temperature inversions on Earth. Heating through sunlight is limited because of Fairbanks's high-latitude location. At the winter solstice
column42: the center of the sun's disk is less than two degrees over the horizon (1.7 degrees) at the local noon (not the time zone noon). Fairbanks experiences 3 hours and 41 minutes of sunlight on December 21 and 22. At the summer solstice
column45: Fairbanks receives 21 hours and 49 minutes of sunlight. After sunset
column46: twilight is bright enough to allow daytime activities without any electric lights
column47: since the center of the sun's disk is just 1.7 degrees below horizon. During winter
column48: the direction of the wind also causes large temperature swings in Fairbanks. When the wind blows from any direction but the south
column49: average weather ensues. Wind from the south can carry warm
column50: moist air from the Gulf of Alaska
column51: greatly warming temperatures. When coupled with a chinook wind
column52: temperatures well above freezing often result: for example
column54: Fairbanks’ average maximum was 28.7 °F (−1.8 °C) and 15 days had a maximum above freezing
column55: whilst during a spell of sustained chinook winds from December 4 to 8
column56: 1934 the temperature topped 50 °F or 10 °C for five consecutive days.In addition to the chinook wind
column57: Fairbanks experiences a handful of other unusual meteorological conditions. In summer
column58: dense wildfire smoke accumulates in the Tanana Valley
column59: affecting the weather and causing health concerns. When temperature inversions arise in winter
column60: heavy ice fog often results. Ice fog occurs when air is too cold to absorb additional moisture
column61: such as that released by automobile engines or human breath. Instead of dissipating
column62: the water freezes into microscopic crystals that are suspended in the air
column63: forming fog. Another one of Fairbanks' unusual occurrences is the prevalence of the aurora borealis
column65: which are visible on average more than 200 days per year in the vicinity of Fairbanks. The northern lights are not visible in the summer months due to the 24 hour daylight of the midnight sun. Fairbanks also has extremely low seasonal lag; the year's warmest month is July
column66: which averages only 2.1 °F (1.2 °C) warmer than June. Average daily temperatures begin to fall by late July and more markedly in August
column67: which on average is 4.3 °F (2.4 °C) cooler than June.From 1949 to 2018
column68: Fairbanks's mean annual temperature has risen by 3.9 °F (2.2 °C)
column69: a change comparable to the Alaska-wide average; winter was the season with the highest increase
column73: the mean annual temperature increase from 1976 to 2018 in Fairbanks stood at a more moderate 0.7 °F (0.39 °C); this stepwise temperature change
column75: is explained by the Pacific Decadal Oscillation shifting from a negative phase to a positive phase from 1976 onward.

It has hosted many different big ski events including the 2003 Junior Olympic Cross Country Ski Championship and the 2008 and 2009 U.S. Cross Country Distance Nationals It also has an annual 50k race called the Sonot Kkaazoot and the Fairbanks Town Series races which consists of four different races and the Chest Medicine Distance Series races which consists of only 3 races.

column1: The majority of Fairbanks is politically conservative
column2: with three distinct geographical areas representing differing ideological views. The western part of the city
column3: centered on the University of Alaska Fairbanks
column4: is Democratic-leaning. The downtown area and the eastern parts near Fort Wainwright are Republican-leaning
column5: and the North Pole area farther east is even more conservative. Thus
column6: many residents have noted that a neighborhood's position on the map of Fairbanks (west to east) mirrors its political orientation (left to right).

column5: and a portion of one other district

column1: Fairbanksans elected the first two Libertarian Party members to serve in a state legislature in the United States. Dick Randolph
column2: who had previously served two terms in the Alaska House as a Republican

column1: Fairbanks is a regional center for most departments of the State of Alaska

unlike other larger cities in Alaska
column3: still has separate borough and city governments. The City of Fairbanks was incorporated on November 10

column1: The Fairbanks Police Department is the law enforcement agency responsible for the city. Since its establishment

column1: Electricity is provided by the Golden Valley Electric Association. The Chena power site has four steam turbines fueled by coal and one oil-fueled electrical generator. Interior Alaska is not connected to the electrical grid of the contiguous United States and Canada
column2: but a transmission line constructed in 1985 connects Fairbanks with power plants in the coal-producing area of Healy and the Anchorage area. Fairbanks currently holds the world record for the largest rechargeable battery
column4: 300 tons. The battery was installed to help bridge the gaps that occur during frequent power outages. The battery will provide power for 7 minutes to about 12
column5: 000 homes.The University of Alaska Fairbanks operates its own coal-fired generating station on campus
column6: providing electricity and steam heat to university buildings.Until 1996
column7: telephone service was provided by the Municipal Utilities Service
column8: a public company. In that year
column9: telephone service was sold to Alaska Communications Systems
column10: a private company. General Communications Inc. has competed against ACS in Fairbanks since 1997. Both companies offer mobile phone service in Fairbanks
column11: as do national and local providers such as AT&T Mobility and Verizon Wireless.A pair of fiber optic cables provide long-distance telephone and Internet service. One parallels the Parks Highway and connects Fairbanks to Anchorage
column12: while the other parallels the Richardson Highway and connects Fairbanks to Valdez. A third
column13: spur fiber optic cable parallels the Trans-Alaska Pipeline and connects Fairbanks to Prudhoe Bay. Broadband Internet access is provided by GCI
column15: Ace Tekk and a handful of satellite Internet and wireless Internet services.

column1: As the transportation hub for Interior Alaska
column2: Fairbanks features extensive road
column4: and air connections to the rest of Alaska and Outside. At Fairbanks' founding
column5: the only way to reach the new city was via steamboat on the Chena River. In 1904
column6: money intended to improve the Valdez-Eagle Trail was diverted to build a branch trail
column7: giving Fairbanks its first overland connection to the outside world. The resulting Richardson Highway was created in 1910 after Gen. Wilds P. Richardson upgraded it to a wagon road. In the 1920s
column8: it was improved further and made navigable by automobiles
column9: but it was not paved until 1957.Fairbanks' road connections were improved in 1927
column10: when the 161-mile (259 km) Steese Highway connected the city to the Yukon River at the gold-mining community of Circle. In 1942
column11: the Alaska Highway connected the Richardson Highway to the Canadian road system
column12: allowing road travel from the rest of the United States to Fairbanks
column13: which is considered the unofficial end of the highway. Because of World War II
column14: civilian traffic was not permitted on the highway until 1948.In the late 1960s and early 1970s
column15: a series of roads were built to connect Fairbanks to the oil fields of Prudhoe Bay. The Elliott Highway was built in 1957 to connect Fairbanks to Livengood
column16: southern terminus of the Dalton Highway
column17: which ends in Deadhorse on the North Slope. West of the Dalton intersection
column18: the Elliott Highway extends to Manley Hot Springs on the Tanana River. To improve logistics in Fairbanks during construction of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline
column19: the George Parks Highway was built between Fairbanks and Palmer in 1971.Until 1940
column20: none of Fairbanks' surface streets were paved. The outbreak of World War II interrupted plans to pave most of the city's roads
column21: and a movement toward large-scale paving did not begin until 1953
column22: when the city paved 30 blocks of streets. During the late 1950s and the 1960s
column23: the remainder of the city's streets were converted from gravel roads to asphalt surfaces. Few have been repaved since that time; a 2008 survey of city streets indicated the average age of a street in Fairbanks was 31 years.Public transportation has been provided by the Metropolitan Area Commuter System
column24: an agency of the borough government
column25: since 1977. Bus service links much of the urban Fairbanks area
column26: with most routes connecting at the downtown transit center. University Bus Lines
column28: existed for several decades before MACS started. The company
column29: which was owned first by Paul Greimann and later by Walt Conant
column30: mainly linked downtown Fairbanks with the university campus and the military bases.

column1: Fairbanks International Airport serves as a major hub for Alaska air travel. Several regional and charter airlines use or have used the location as their main base of operations due to its central location in the state. Commercial airlines also connect Fairbanks to the lower 48 and select international destinations. Fairbanks is the smallest city in the United States to be served by transatlantic flights
column2: as Condor operates direct flight to Frankfurt in the summer tourist season.

column1: After large-scale gold mining began north of Fairbanks
column2: miners wanted to build a railroad from the steamboat docks on the Chena River to the mine sites in the hills north of the city. The result was the Tanana Mines Railroad
column4: using what had been the first steam locomotive in the Yukon Territory. In 1907
column5: the railroad was reorganized and named the Tanana Valley Railroad. The railroad continued expanding until 1910
column6: when the first gold boom began to falter and the introduction of automobiles into Fairbanks took business away from the railroad. Despite these problems
column7: railroad backers envisioned a rail line extending from Fairbanks to Seward on the Gulf of Alaska
column8: home to the Alaska Central Railway.In 1914
column9: the US Congress appropriated $35 million for construction of the Alaska Railroad system
column10: but work was delayed by the outbreak of World War I. Three years later
column11: the Alaska Railroad purchased the Tanana Valley Railroad
column12: which had suffered from the wartime economic problems. Rail workers built a line extending northwest from Fairbanks
column14: where President Warren G. Harding hammered in the ceremonial final spike in 1923. The rail yards of the Tanana Valley Railroad were converted for use by the Alaska Railroad
column15: and Fairbanks became the northern end of the line and its second-largest depot.From 1923 to 2004
column16: the Alaska Railroad's Fairbanks terminal was in downtown Fairbanks
column17: just north of the Chena River. In May 2005
column18: the Alaska Railroad opened a new terminal northwest of downtown
column19: and that terminal is in operation today. In summer
column20: the railroad operates tourist trains to and from Fairbanks
column21: and it operates occasional passenger trains throughout the year. The majority of its business through Fairbanks is freight. The railroad is planning an expansion of the rail line from Fairbanks to connect the city via rail with Delta Junction

column1: Compared to communities of similar population
column2: Fairbanks' crime rate (violent and property crimes combined) is higher than Alaska's average

column1: Fairbanks similarly has a higher than average rate of rape and sexual assault

column1: The city of Fairbanks and the greater Fairbanks area is home to a number of attractions and events
column2: which draw visitors from outside of Alaska throughout the year. Summer tourist traffic primarily consists of cruise ship passengers who purchase package tours which include travel to Fairbanks. Many of these tourists spend one or more nights at a local hotel and visit one or more attractions. Tourism the rest of the year is mostly concentrated around the winter season
column4: ice carving and winter sports. In addition
column5: other events draw visitors from within Alaska
column6: mostly from the community's trading area throughout Interior Alaska and the North Slope.
